Proclamation for the Denver St. Patrick': 'speaker_1': 'Thank you, Councilmember Cashman. And we'd like to wish a happy birthday to Councilmember Black, who is not here, but whose birthday is tomorrow. There are no presentations this evening. There are no communications. We have one proclamation being read this evening.'
'speaker_1': 'Councilmember CdeBaca, will you please read Proclamation 20 2-0276.'

'speaker_4': 'Thank you. Yes, I can. Proclamation number 22 to 76 congratulating the Denver St Patrick's Day Parade Committee on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the annual parade on March 12, 2022. Whereas Denver has one of the largest cultural parades in the United States and the largest Saint Patrick's Day parade west of the Mississippi.'

'speaker_4': 'And. Whereas, this year's theme is centered around the return of the Irish and honors the 60th anniversary of the parade. And. Whereas, the Denver St Patrick's Day Parade exemplifies a peaceful celebration among the community of diverse citizens who gather together with a glance toward the Celtic past and a look toward the future while enjoying Irish cultural fanfare'

'speaker_4': ', pipe and drum bands, Irish step dancing and honoring all divisions of our military to the delight of over 300,000 spectators. And. Whereas, we offer our congratulations and thanks to all volunteers of the Denver St Patrick's Day Parade Committee, including many who have passed on but are still remembered for their endless hours and never ending commitment, which is'

'speaker_4': 'what makes this celebration possible. And. Whereas, we hope the Colorado Sun and the Mile High Air lifts the spirits of all who marched or attend the 60th Annual Parade on Saturday, March 12, 2022. And we hope for a warm wind at our backs as we celebrate the Irish culture in the great state of Colorado.'

'speaker_4': 'Now, therefore, be it proclaimed by the Council of the City and County of Denver that the Council hereby congratulates the Denver St Patrick's Day Parade Committee, a volunteer organization on a well-organized, peaceful and spirited gathering at the 60th annual event, and that the clerk and Clerk of the city and county of Denver shall test and affix the'
'speaker_4': 'seal of the city and county of Denver to this proclamation and that a copy be transmitted to the Denver St Patrick's Day Parade Committee President Michael O'Neill. Thank you.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you, Councilmember CdeBaca. Your motion to adopt.'
'speaker_4': 'I move that proclamation 22 dash to 76, be adopted.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you. It's been moved and seconded. Comments by members of Council. Council member CdeBaca.'

'speaker_4': 'Thank you very much. Just very happy to have this proclamation this year and actually see a potential parade happening. Last year this was the beginning of everything getting shut down and so very excited to welcome you all here and welcome the parade back to Denver.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you. Council member. Council member. Flynn.'

'speaker_5': 'Thank you, Madam President. If I could just have some indulgence for a brief period here for a comment. About 17 years ago, I took my kids over to Ireland and we had the honor of visiting in County Galway, the little town where my Flynn ancestors from which they left during the potato famine, to come to America to'

'speaker_5': 'find a better life. And while we were on the way from La Croix to Galway itself, we passed through the the town of Gort, where William Butler Yeats Castle Tours Abahlali is situated. And while we were in there in the gift shop, my kids bought me a a.'

'speaker_5': 'A framed photo or a framed print of one of Yeats's most celebrated poems. It's very short. Madam President, I would like to read it, especially in this time when world peace is being threatened. We need to hear these words from the great Irish poet William Butler Yeats.'

'speaker_5': 'The Lake Isle of Innisfree. I will rise now and go and go to Innisfree. And a small cabin build there of clay and wattles made nine bean rows, while I have there a hive for the honeybee. And live alone in the be loud glade.'

'speaker_5': 'And I shall have some peace there. For peace comes dropping, slow dropping from the veils of the morning to where the cricket sings. There Midnight's All, a glimmer and noon, a purple glow. And the evening full of the linnet swings.'

'speaker_5': 'I will rise and go now for always, night and day. I hear lake water lapping with low sounds by the shore. While I stand on the roadway or on the pavements. Gray I hear it in the deep hardcore.'
'speaker_5': 'Thank you, Madam President.'

'speaker_1': 'Thank you very much, Councilmember Flynn. Those are amazing words and we can always be reminded of that. So thank you so much for doing that and I am very happy to support this tonight and look forward to finally having a parade and celebrating a little bit in our city.'

'speaker_4': 'Thank you. I'd like to later invite committee president Mr. O'Neill and whoever else I would like to accept with him.'

'speaker_5': 'Thank you so much for that. Ladies and gentlemen, I just want to start a little bit here. We're one of the few groups that that comes before you each year with a little bit of a serenade from the pipes and a song called Danny Boy before I make my remarks.'

'speaker_5': 'Distinguished members of the Denver City Council. My name is Michael O'Neill and the president of the Denver St Patrick's Day Parade Committee. 'speaker_5': 'I want to also make sure to thank the Office of Special Events, the Denver Fire Department, the Denver Police Department, the City Excise and Licensing Department. 'speaker_5': 'And as part of that, I'd like to introduce a couple of distinguished members here with me. 'speaker_5': 'Mr. Shamrock, that's going to be here. But I. I just want to let you know, I had a profound thought here in the last couple of days that it's amazing that we've lived through the last two years of COVID, and we've separated ourselves and we've not had that sense of community that we've had before the advent of'

'speaker_5': 'the pandemic. And it's amazing that it's the Irish community that is now hosting the largest gathering of citizens across our country, starting with the Mile High City. 'speaker_5': 'And with that, I leave you with our theme. The Irish are back. Thank you very much.'

'speaker_1': 'And so thank you again and congratulations. All right. We're going to go ahead and move on here. Madam Secretary, would you please read the bills for introduction?'

'speaker_6': 'Thank you, Madam President. I just wanted to call out and really thank the folks involved with this. Ultimately, I see you in the audience from the Office of Immigrant and Refugee Affairs. This this bill awards additional funds for the Denver Immigrant Legal Services Fund.'

'speaker_6': 'And when this first fund was first started, it was with 100,000 of city funds and $100,000 grant from Vera. This most recent distribution put out just over half a million dollars into community organizations to provide legal services for immigrants, both in defense and affirmative relief.'

'speaker_6': 'And I just want to thank the city and a team's team and the committee for this work and to remind folks that this is an open fund. So this is not just something that's funded by the city. It also takes your donations.'

'speaker_6': 'So businesses, philanthropic sources, community members and residents can also donate to this fund and really make a difference for somebody to have that legal support to apply for citizenship, to renew their license to defend themselves in immigration court.'
'speaker_6': 'So just really want to call out the progress in this effort and think the work of a team. Thank you.'

'speaker_6': 'Thank you so much, Madam President. I was excited to see that my colleague, Councilwoman Torres, called this out. And I just want to echo her thanks to really the community partners who led, I think back in the day when Councilman Lopez was sitting in this very chair, actually, the very end of the dais was his spot.'

'speaker_6': 'And hearing that call worked with the administration and really pushed, I think, beyond what was the comfort zone at that time. You know, this is critical to our community. These individuals, many of whom have claims to stay in the country.'

'speaker_6': 'They have statuses, but they just don't know how to assert them in court by themselves without an attorney. They are parents of children in our community, which we are responsible for if something happens to them and they're not able to care for those kids.'

'speaker_6': 'They are parts of our community. They work in jobs that are helping to maintain our city. And so we really are interconnected, right? The immigrant members of our community are part of the fabric. And if you unravel that fabric, the entire cloth right.'

'speaker_6': 'Becomes weakened. So I really want to appreciate the way that we have seen this grow. And I want to give kudos to Councilwoman Torres, who's been a champion, and we've got to partner on some of these increases together.'

'speaker_6': 'And I think the one thing I will just add about the donation fund is that, you know, when we see events in the world and I think all had hope that some of the border issues, some of the immigration issues were going to get better in this administration.'

'speaker_6': 'And it's been hard. Congress has been unable to be a partner and to get any meaningful immigration reform passed. And so, honestly, this is as critically needed today as it was in the darkest days of the last administration.'

'speaker_6': 'It hurts my heart to say that I don't think it's for lack of of of desire to make change. But if you feel like you see images of immigrants and refugees and those who are struggling and, you know, the idea of how we keep our community inclusive, please consider contributing.'

'speaker_6': 'Companies should be contributing to this. These are workers in your businesses whose families are affected by this. So so I hope that we can all, you know, become aware of the ways to give our treasure to something that means something to our community.'
'speaker_6': 'So thank you very much. And it's on consent, but I'm very excited that we're going to be voting on it tonight. Thanks.'

'speaker_1': 'Thank you. Councilmember Khanna. Each and my only request beyond my thanks and gratitude for working on this is that we make sure and get out to council offices the information so that we can share it out to our constituents.'

'speaker_4': 'Thank you. This is first reading and so it will come up again in front of us. But I want to go on record at this meeting and I'll be a no next reading as not supporting this. As you may recall, I'm a staunch supporter of the auditor's request for subpoena power.'

'speaker_4': 'I believe it's a critical component of his work and to the transparency our Denver residents have so frequently demanded from our government. If you're watching the news, members of the public, there are legal actions being pursued by the auditor for what he believes was an overreach of council's power.'

'speaker_4': 'An amendment in an amendment that made it into this bill when it was passed last spring. There are three branches of government, of course. The mayors, the executive branch councils, the legislative branch and the courts are our third branch.'

'speaker_4': 'There are three branches of government to serve as checks and balances to each other for a reason. Because this issue is in litigation, I feel that it is in fact an overreach for us to pull the ordinance out completely through a flat out repeal, rather than allowing the issue to be resolved either in court or by conducting'
'speaker_4': 'a brand new process to find a better solution mutually. While this ordinance remains in effect. So for that, I'm a note tonight. Thank you.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you. Councilmember CdeBaca. Councilmember Flynn.'

'speaker_5': 'Thank you, Madam President. I think if I recall last May's debate on this accurately. Most members of this body want the auditor to have subpoena power and would vote that way and in fact, did give him subpoena power.'

'speaker_5': 'He has it. We put a few guardrails in for the in the interest of security of confidential and proprietary data. But this repeal is necessary now and to start over. I agree with Councilwoman CdeBaca. We will start over because we want the auditor to be able to do proper investigations.'

'speaker_5': 'But this repeal is necessary to prevent the waste and abuse of taxpayer money that is triggered by the auditor's ill advised decision to file a meritless lawsuit. Repeal removes any basis for it. The auditor suit asks the judicial branch to usurp the role of city council and hand the auditor a version of the ordinance that could not'

'speaker_5': 'have passed this body. That is an attack on the independence of the council and the separation of powers that we just heard about from Councilwoman CdeBaca. He did this in place of authentically engaging with us. So while the lawsuit is doomed to fail, the lawyers bills to the taxpayer would be all too real and a waste.'

'speaker_5': 'This council last year was frustrated by the auditor's refusal to engage with us in the legislative process and address very real and serious concerns over how he would handle proprietary and confidential data. Because of this refusal, culminating in his absence from the council meeting where the vote was being taken, the final vote, his request for subpoena authority'

'speaker_5': 'that night was headed for defeat. In order to give him that subpoena authority that most members want him to have. I proposed this amendment in order to save the bill. Without my amendment, his bill would have died on the floor with my amendment.'

'speaker_5': 'The auditor would have the authority to subpoena any and all data, documents and information, including complete access to all confidential and proprietary information held by entities being audited. But it allowed those entities, if they chose to require that only, only proprietary or confidential data had to be examined on site instead of being copied and taken away to'

'speaker_5': 'the auditor's office. Since then, the auditor has made many misleading and incorrect statements about this ordinance, most notably that the amendment allows outside parties being audited to withhold information. It does no such thing at all. His decision to refuse examining confidential or proprietary information on site is not the same as being denied access to it.'

'speaker_5': 'Audit subjects had legitimate fears about sending their sensitive, proprietary and confidential data out the door on a flash drive, especially knowing that the auditor would extract that data and upload it into third party applications outside their oversight. So after the ordinance is replaced, is repealed.'

'speaker_5': 'Rather, it is my intention to start outrage over a new bill to reestablish subpoena authority for the auditor in the area, especially of wage investigations and enforcement only at first, which we all want or most of us want, while inviting the auditor reengage on the use of subpoenas in performance and internal audits.'
'speaker_5': 'And we hope, Madam President, for serious cooperation and authentic engagement this time around. Thank you.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you. Councilmember Flynn. Councilmember Sawyer.'

'speaker_6': 'Thanks, Madam President. I just wanted to reiterate points both my colleagues made. I do think it's incredibly important that the auditor have subpoena power. And so I hate to repeal this tonight, but at the end of the day, process matters.'

'speaker_6': 'And the process that we went through is the governmental process of the city and county of Denver. 'speaker_6': 'hearing, you know, maybe things would have been different. But that didn't happen. And process matters. So as much as I hate to do this tonight, I am going to agree and vote yes that we should repeal this ordinance and start the process over again.'
'speaker_6': 'I'm not happy about it, but you know, this is the best choice in order to save taxpayer dollars, which I think is the most important right now. Thanks.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you. Councilmember Sawyer. Councilman Cashman.'
